text: WILL RIPLEY: Yeah, we

from North Korean officials
about this launch, Ivan,

because if there is a failure,
it is not acknowledged
in North Korean state media.

And in fact, KCNA and
KCTV, their television--

state-controlled TV station
here have been broadcasting,

and there's been
no mention of this.
And there won't be.

I've been in the country
on other occasions

where there are failed
missile launches
that are never acknowledged.

If it were a success, however,
you would see, likely,

photos of the successful
launch, perhaps

the North Korean
leader Kim Jong Un
overseeing the whole operation.

And the message that they would
be trying to send, of course,

is continued defiance against
the United States, which

is engaged in joint military
exercises with South Korea;

defiance against the US for
deploying the USS Carl Vinson

carrier strike
group in the waters

off the Korean
peninsula; defiance

over the missile strike
against the Syrian regime.

And of course, this is just
after-- one day after-- the Day

of the Sun military parade,
where North Korea displayed

more missiles than they
ever have in the past,

according to analysts, including
two potential ICBMs that
have never been seen before.

Analysts, of course, have no way
of knowing how far along North

Korea is in its progress
with the development

of these intercontinental
ballistic missiles

that could eventually
carry a nuclear warhead as
far away as the United States.

But I've spoken with a
number of experts who believe

that if North Korea continues
its testing at this pace,

successes and failures
factored in here, Ivan,

they could be just
a couple of years

away from having that
type of a weapon.
